learning_outcomes.description: Describe and explain a range of contemporary learning theories and in relation to these theories, identify optimal conditions for learning.
Reflect on the impact of physical, social and intellectual development and characteristics of students and how these may affect learning.
Apply knowledge of contemporary learning theories to learning in primary education settings.
Use appropriate communication skills to present clear, coherent and independent exposition of knowledge and ideas studied in this course.

assessments.task_description:
For this task, you will present some contemporary literature on learning and development. You will need to find and discuss readings that focus on both of the following areas:

1) How primary school students develop and learn in general (aspects of general learning theories discussed in the course)

2) The physical, social and intellectual/cognitive aspects of development and learning (one example for physical, social and intellectual/cognitive learning in primary schools each)

You will prepare an annotated bibliography including six references. You may use three readings included in this course (chapters/sections that are set for weekly readings, or any of the additional readings listed in the course profile), but you must use at least three other readings that you have found yourself. The three other readings that you find yourself have to be journal articles from peer-reviewed journals in the UQ databases, published from 2015 onwards (so, no articles that were published earlier than 2015).

Format

The total word count for this task is 2,000 words. The full reference of your annotated literature sources are included in the word count. Any additional references that you might use in your annotations must be listed at the end of the assignment, but these additional references are not counted in the word count. 

Each annotation will include:

  • A brief introduction to the area(s) 
  • The full reference in APA 7th edition format
  • A summary of the chapter/article including the main points
  • A statement of the key message being conveyed by the author(s) 
  • An interpretation of the strengths and limitations of the work (critical analysis of the content, ideas and research methods)

At the end of the review, provide a summary about what the six articles in combination might tell us about learning and development theories in education. This summary should include implications for teachers.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this task, you will design a learning activity for primary students. The topic area covered in the activity can be in your preferred curriculum area or otherwise (e.g. English/Literacy; Maths/Numeracy; Social Sciences, etc). The activity should be engaging, interactive and based on a student-centred, constructivist approach to education, and reflect an understanding of adolescent brain development and the most efficient and effective processes of knowledge acquisition. The activity should consider the function of memory and the need to minimise cognitive overload (CC 1.2 – assessed). The activity can be 20-60 minutes in length. You do not need to design a whole lesson, just one activity. The one activity might have an introductory section, a middle part, and a conclusive section that might include a retrieval task to consolidate understanding.

The assignment has two parts: 

 1. Activity Plan

You will design an activity plan using a template provided to you on Blackboard. The activity plan will be approximately 500 – 800 words. 

You will need to provide a description of: 

• The context for the activity, where and how it should be done, what knowledge domain (e.g. science; literacy etc) it is in and any other critical information that other teachers would need to know in advance of implementing the activity. You may reference the Australian Curriculum or Queensland Syllabus documents.

• The intended outcomes of the activity and how it supports knowledge acquisition, and promotes engagement without creating cognitive overload - what do you think the primary students will be able to do or understand at the end of the activity and how does it build on prior knowledge?

• The resources required for the activity – worked examples, paper, URLs, skipping ropes.....anything in terms of technical materials, tools and sources of information that you will need to do this activity with your students

• A description of what students will be doing - what will you ask the primary students to do at each phase of the activity, how will the activity be designed to reduce extraneous load, will they work alone or in groups/with partners, will there be opportunities to self-check on their progress, and so on.

• An outline of the instructional guidance for the activity, including where relevant, explicit instruction, worked examples, provision of relevant strategies, scaffolded supports, techniques that support the function of memory, etc. 

Design justification

The second part of the assignment involves you providing a justification for the design. This section will be approximately 1000 - 1500 words. In this section, you will need to cover the following:

• A description of the learning and development concepts that underpins your design, including a demonstration of an understanding of brain structure, function and development (design: the decisions you took when developing the activity)

• A justification for why the development and learning theories were chosen - provide specific details of theory concepts, ideas and strategies

• An explanation of how you have drawn on the theory to inform the decisions you made in designing the activity - provide specific details of theory concepts, ideas and strategies

• The range of teaching strategies that will need to be employed during the activity

• A justification for the resources selected for use in the activity

• A brief reflection on what this task has helped you to understand about how learning and development theories inform practice

• Consider student diversity for all of the above (differentiation)

• A minimum of four references should be used to support your justification and reflection.

assessments.task_description:
As future teachers, you are required to:

1. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of physical, social and intellectual development and characteristics of students and how these may affect learning

2. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of research into how students learn and the implications for teaching.

3. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of strategies for differentiating teaching to meet the specific learning needs of students across the full range of abilities.

4. Demonstrate an understanding of the brain (structure, function, development) and learning. 

This reflective journal entry task enables you to demonstrate your abilities across all these areas. To assist you in maintaining momentum in your course, you are required to complete 6 activities that are tied to the learning in this course, submitted online.  

In order to achieve in this assessment, you will need to:

1. Participate in all weekly lectures, workshops and tutorials (including preparation of weekly readings for class discussion).  

2. Complete your journal at regular intervals throughout the Semester (as outlined below).  

You will be provided with question prompts throughout the semester in line with the topics we will cover. For each of these topics, you will write 200-300 word journal entries in response to each of the question prompts. and add at least one specific reference to course readings you have read in the preparation of your reflection. This may include a chapter/excerpt from your textbook and/or a reading from the course reading list. The reference is not included in the word count. Please note: your journal entry reflections need to be based on readings, lectures and tutorials in this course. Please reflect on what you have encountered in this course, and how you might have experienced learning situations yourself that remind you of the concepts, ideas and theories you have read or learnt about in this course.

1. Why is it important for educators to be aware of, and understand current research evidence on how children develop and learn? Due beginning of week 3

2. Reflect on some key aspects of physical, intellectual/cognitive and social/emotional learning? How and why are they interrelated? What are the most important elements of learning theories that teachers may need to support their educational practices? Due beginning of week 5

3. What are the key influences on brain development during childhood and how can an understanding of these inform the design of learning experiences for students in primary school? Which neuromyths should we avoid and why? (CC 1.4 – assessed) Due beginning of week 7

4. Select one effective evidence-based strategy from the following list (retrieval practice, spaced practice, interleaving, dual coding): explain how it can assist knowledge acquisition and memory consolidation, and reduce cognitive load, and give an example of how it could be applied into practice in the primary school classroom. (CC 1.2 – assessed) Due beginning of week 9

5. What aspects of cognitive development will teachers take account of when designing and adjusting learning experiences for students in primary schools? What pedagogical practices and classroom routines can support novice learners to progress towards mastery? Provide brief examples. (CC 1.1, 1.3 – assessed) Due beginning of week 11

6. Which aspect(s) of social/emotional and physical development do you think will be a key to understanding your students when you are in the classroom? Justify your choices with brief examples. Due beginning of week 12 

Your journal entry reflections are due on Mondays by 2pm.

In week 13, you will be required to submit a single document including all your journal entries and an additional 200-300 word reflection on how your thinking has changed and evolved over the semester, with regards to concepts and ideas from learning theories you have encountered. This single document with all your journal entries and the additional reflection will be marked as per the criteria sheet. You will need to provide references to the literature covered in the course to support your journal entries.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Weekly journals are submitted in a Blackboard tool.

c. Attention and Executive Functions (CC 1.1.3, 1.2.3, 2.2.3, 2.2.1 – Taught; CC 1.1.3, 2.2.5 – Practised)

d. Designing for Learning (1.1.4, 1.2.3, 1.3.2, 1.3.3, 2.2.3, 2.2.6 – Taught; CC 1.2.3, 1.3.2, 1.3.3, 2.2.1, 2.2.3, 2.2.5, 2.2.6 – Practised)
